reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer/publisher.
Better Late Than DEAD is a survival adventure game developed by Odin Game Studios, being published on Steam in July of 2015 on Early Access.

As we have come all too familiar with the survival genre of games; you start off as a single character, dropped in the middle of nowhere and you are expected to survive.  Games of this genre are often a hit from the start or just flop straight away. Unfortunately Better Late Than DEAD does not have a very bright future in my eyes.

Gameplay is…well, almost none existent. I started out in the ocean and had to swim at least five minutes before I got to any sort of land. I spent almost an hour exploring the island, finding a couple of houses, and that is it. Whilst exploring the houses I found that each of them had their own loot, strangely enough, the houses were all an exact copy of each other and the loot was spawned in exactly the same place.  The loot that I found were again, everything you would expect to find in this type of game, cans of food, bandages, knives, etc. As far as game play goes, that is it. There is absolutely nothing else to do in this game; I didn’t find any animals, enemies, nothing.

The graphics are bad to say the least; the screenshots really shows the game in a different light to how it actually looks in real time. Awfully low quality textures on almost everything, the water certainly doesn’t look like how it does in the screenshots, and neither does the skybox. On top of the poor graphics, the animation side of the game is horrible; your character has just an awful run cycle that looks like some sort of jelly man was used to rig it – also this game features possibly one of the highest jumping ability I have ever seen in a game, I swear I was jumping up entire flights of stairs in one go… It should also be known, that from jumping, I managed to break my leg in the game twice and die from it once – lord knows how.

At the beginning of the game, I was presented with a cut scene that sets up for a quite interesting story; but that is it. After that intro, I found no other plot elements, or anything. I was particularly disappointed as I would have really liked to have seen more of it. Hopefully the developers will be adding something in via patches in the future on this aspect.

Better Late Than DEAD also has some audio problems. Whilst playing the game, you will have the same repetitive soundtrack playing in the background, and when it loops, boy do you notice it. There is an obvious cut in the track, and it just starts playing again; this for me seemed like a really basic issue which should not be seen in the game, it really ruined the game’s immersion (the little it actually had).

I really expected the world I was in to be full of interesting environments and buildings to explore, but sadly due to the copy/paste nature shown in the game, it all seemed to blur together and nothing really stood out as interesting. All of the buildings are exactly the same layout, tress look exactly the same, it just looks like someone has gone in and press CTRL A CTRL V over and over again to make it seem like the world is huge.

Sadly the game is very poorly optimized. Whilst the game has the options to run on all resolutions up to 4k, it certainly doesn’t run well. Playability is none existent at 4k, so I had to drop it to 1080p, and even then, I was not able to reach 60 fps and that is with my monster rig.  This needs to be the top of their agenda at the very least.

At the time of writing this review, I have been playing for just over two hours; I honestly don’t see myself jumping into the game any time again soon, unless there are some major changes and improvements on what the game currently has. The last update to the game from what I can see is 18th November 2015, and even then, only two new additions to the game were added.  If anyone is interested in the survival genre, there are definitely games out there that are still in early access, and are in a much much better state than this game at the moment. Even though the game is retailing for £6,99, I still cannot recommend this game. It may improve, but it is going to take a lot for it to be even worthy of that low price.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR
Better Late than Dead is too early access to recommend spending your hard-earned cash on, unless you're a die-hard fan of survival games (like there aren't enough to choose from).


Better Late than Dead is a game that is still marred hugely by it's early access state. For those familiar with survival games, BLTD is the quintessential example - but with too many flaws currently to rationalize the price.

BTLD is a game of too many button presses. In most games, you could press E or F to pick up a nearby item. In BTLD you must right-click to zoom in (on an already slightly off camera angle, another thing that bothered me), pan over to the item in question with a slightly unreasonable amount of exactness, and left click.
The inventory systems mirrors this as well. Clicking an item current brings up a context menu, but the only options currently are to drop or equip something. This means that all food, water, bandages, etc must be used from the quickbar, when in many cases it could be more easily used straight from the inventory. This issue is exaserbated by the fact that there are only 4(?!) quickbar slots. Eating a mango should be a quick trip to the inventory, but it is instead a matter of equipping it, activating it, and THEN eating it. Pressing the relevant quickbar key doesn't automatically activate, you must click another time before watching your character enter into an awkward eating animation.

Speaking of animations, that is another thing this game does poorly from what I saw. The character runs in a very goofy fashion, especially if he becomes injured. Injury seems to be incurred too easily - I walked for several in-game hours on a broken ankle or whatever caused by jumping off a rock that didn't come up to the character's knees.

Lastly, the character model is pretty ugly. His beard doesn't look even the least bit natural, and neither does his butt. It seriously looks like the left side is twice the side of his right, which is made worse by the aforementioned running animation. You're probably thinking, I could seriously care less about this character's butt"
recommended: you'll be looking at it for the majority of your time playing BLTD."

Alright, so after I had this game in my library untouched for months, I decided to play it.
I'm a huge fan of survival games, thus my decision to purchasing this game wondering what it will be like.

Ok, so you strand on an island, there is body bags everywhere of dead people, sometimes next to them is food, idk why but there just is. Don't worry you can eat it, as this is the main resource to get rid of your hunger bar, same for thirst.

It took me a while to figure out how to cut trees aswell, at first I thought trees were attacking me as soon as I started to hit them, little did I know I was actually cutting them, thus I got sticks. Ok so to bundle this up:

Pros:
- I actually liked the way how you were able to pick up items.
- Sleeping works.

Cons:

- Only 10% of the island can be used for resources.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First thing I realized about this game...Massive mouse acceleration. From the instant you go into this game, you get slapped with that function. Lowering the mouse sensitivity doesn't change much.

Second, combat still needs a lot of work. Currently, I took on an alligator on a 1v1 match. Me with a knife, him or her with it's alligator skin and sharp teeth. I only lost about 30% of my health even though I was attacking it with a knife over the course of the fight. Apparently the wildlife flinches if you hit them so they don't attack you back. Who was the genius who implemented that? Anyways, when you're in combat and in the middle of doing an action, you can't really move your camera. So when your character swings a knife down and your prey(or enemy moves), you have to watch as your character moves back into position and then you can slowly swing your character towards the enemy again. But the most ♥♥♥♥ed up thing would be that a different alligator took me from the 70% health I was at to maybe around 5% with just one bite. I was running from a lake when I saw two alligators next to each other. I figured I would try skirting around them so to save some energy but one turns to me, nips me on my heel, and I nearly die. Freakin' unbelievable. I mean, choose one or the other. If you want to make them dangerous, take away the flinching wildlife so that they're a force to be reckoned with. If  you want this game to be easy, nerf their bite or something. Seriously, that ♥♥♥♥ was outrageous.

One thing that's interesting about this game is that it uses this perception concept that's very similar to Tomb Raider(2013) where you press a hotkey and then everything turns black and white for Lara other than things that she can interact with. Same concept for this game, except that it draws on your stamina for some reason. It's okay I guess, although it shows me things that I can't even interact with some times. For instance, I'm in a village and I'm running low on hydration and hunger. So use the perception ability and I see a water pump and a metal bowl filled with water. I walk over to it but nothing works. There's no interact key and I'm left staring at this bowl of water as my hydration meter slowly drops down. Why are the devs making it more complicated than it is? Why doesn't it allow me to drink out of the metal bowl of which the water is coming from an underground source? Do I honestly have to craft some sort of cup or bottle to drink water out of a pump?

The gameplay itself is somewhat lacking. I admit, I was introduced to the survival genre through Minecraft so the first thing I usually do is I go up to a tree and see what I can do to it. In this case, my character just grabs a tree and shakes it. I allow it to shake it a few more times until the game doesn't let me anymore and I'm left wondering what the hell is it trying to tell me to do. Now I haven't played long enough to completely put all the mechanisms down to pat, I've lost interest pretty quickly. Also, having to hold down right click just to interact with items in the world? Are you kidding me? It might sound like a petty complaint but until you've played and realized the absolute horror it is to navigate throughout a room with a ♥♥♥♥ ton of stuff on the ground, you won't understand the pain and agony I went through.

Lastly, I'm running a pretty powerful rig although it's not exactly the best(See my profile page for specs). Even so, I'm running this game on around 60FPS at max while sometimes it dips and stays around 40. Mind you, this is in 720p and the graphics look very subpar, especially during sunset. At sunset, it looks like all the props and assets were filtered with a weird bezel effect in photoshop.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=489541358

Ultimately, the game could use some more work. I do understand that it's Early Access and I do understand that its a fairly new release. But if I'm gonna be completely honest, this market is completely saturated with dozens of survival games where you need something that puts you apart from another. Currently, this feels extremely bland. Of course, the graphics looks somewhat better than some of the other survival games out there, but the gameplay falls short by miles.

Thumbs down for the current Early Access game although I'm fairly optimistic that it'll be improved in the near future.

Day 1 - Woke up on island next to dead body, named him Steve. Steve gave me a letter and some apples and a water bottle, Steve is nice. Started to rain so I left Steve to find shelter, got really cold and started to get sick, ran into what looked like alligators, didnt get close enough to find out. Night 1 - Got very dark, had not sticks could not make a torch, spent the night in the village and surrounding woods looking for sticks and apples, found none. Decided to walk down the shoreline. I miss Steve.

Day 2 - found another small island with a village, swam over and searched around, found a knife, tried to stab a tree to get wood, didn't work. decided to search the small island and found a radio tower, and 5 keys. Swam back to larger island and found another fishing village, same materials found, cloth, oil and keys...so many keys. Wonder if one of them belongs to Steve.

Day 3 - Break of dawn, an apple finally drops from a tree I am overjoyed, losing health fast, inventory is full, dropped lighters, picked up apple, started eating apple....died after taking first bite. Should have stayed with Steve.

Updates are coming in on release day
Devs seem to be very active on the forums
Game will be community driven
Refreshing to see a single player driven game that you can also enjoy with a few friends
Love the opening cinematic and artwork style
Really pretty locations of the areas I have seen
Great price of only 5.49 Euro!
(More to come)

Overall I would say this game is a good bargain for the price of a fast food meal that will go down better and last longer :)
If you love supporting early access games I would recommend this game- It still needs a lot of polish but has the potential to be something great and with no zombies! (That I have seen yet!)

2. Targeting
3. start out with knife
4. perma death is optional (should do this one first)

CONS: This game... Well, to get started, it seems like it was optimized by a caveman, And this comes from a guy with a really nice  computer. The graphics are hard to look at, trees in the distance give you a headache sometimes, and even with some graphic options pumped up, it still kinda looks ♥♥♥♥♥♥. I usually dont care about the graphics, but these... these are hard to look at. The camera feels wobbly and uncontrollable at times, and first person mode is the same. I do wish you could like, sneak up on predators by crouching, or sneak away by crouching, but the animals in this game have the reflex and magical ability of a God. It feels like you are trying to guide your pee into the toilet with morning wood when swimming. The knife animation looks cool at first, but then you realize how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ it is when you attack something. NO SERVER LIST.
LETS LOOK AT THE PROS: So when wielding the knife, you walk differently, and you are in a combat looking mode, and it actually does look nice, even though it is useless. The tree shaking ability seems really cool, even though it kinda ends up just giving you infinite food on the island. You can get sick by a bush, and I still cant grasp how to prevent that from happening, but it seems legit. In order not to freeze and die in rain, you have to get in  a building, which adds some depth to the game. Crafting does exist. There is a really cool pickup mode when picking stuff up, you press the right mouse button to zoom in and it gives you the option to pick stuff up. You can also break bones, lose blood, and not die.
CONCLUSION: It is a good concept, and I hope you get it to support the game. It is full of bugs, and the game at times seems unplayable, but I still kinda enjoy it.
